metadata.title: High-Loading Nano-SnO2 Encapsulated in situ in Three- Dimensional Rigid Porous Carbon for Superior Lithium-Ion Batteries

sections.text:
carbon (OMC) acts as a carbon framework showing a desira-
ble ordered mesoporous structure with an average pore size ( 6 nm) and a high surface area (470.3 m2 g¢1), and the SnO2 NPs ( 10 nm) are highly loaded (up to 80 wt %) and homogeneously distributed within the OMC matrix. As an
anode material for lithium-ion batteries, a SnO2@OMC composite material can deliver an initial charge capacity of 943 mAh g¢1 and retain 68.9 % of the initial capacity after 50 cycles at a current density of 50 mA g¢1, even exhibit a ca-
pacity of 503 mA h g¢1 after 100 cycles at 160 mA g¢1. In situ encapsulation of the SnO2 NPs within an OMC framework contributes to a higher capacity and a better cycling stability
and rate capability in comparison with bare OMC and OMC
ex situ loaded with SnO2 particles (SnO2/OMC). The significantly improved electrochemical performance of the SnO2@ OMC composite can be attributed to the multifunctional OMC matrix, which can facilitate electrolyte infiltration, ac-
celerate charge transfer, and lithium-ion diffusion, and act as a favorable buffer to release reaction strains for lithiation/delithiation of the SnO2 NPs.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been extensively applied in
portable electronic devices and are capable of serving as power sources for hybrid or pure electric vehicles. The electro-
chemical performance of LIBs critically relies on the properties and characteristics of the electrode materials, which are ex-
pected to offer a high specific capacity, an outstanding rate ca-
pability, and an excellent cycling stability together with low costs, safety, and environmental benignity.[1–6] Advanced anode
materials have attracted tremendous research efforts, because the traditional graphite anode has a relatively low theoretical capacity of only 372 mAh g¢1, which could not satisfy the high energy density required for next-generation LIBs.[7, 8] By con-
trast, SnO2-based materials as high-capacity anode materials for LIBs show a higher specific lithium storage capacity, up to 790 mAh g¢1, and a larger lithium packing density.[9–14] However, practical applications of these SnO2-based anode materials are hampered by the severe volumetric expansion and contraction during lithiation and delithiation.[15, 16]
Many efforts have been devoted to overcoming the afore-
mentioned issues. One strategy is to develop nanostructured SnO2 materials, such as nanofibers, [17] nanosheets,[18] and hollow structures,[19] which have been demonstrated to mini-
mize the mechanical reaction strains during the electrochemical cycles of SnO2-based anodes, resulting in a significantly enhanced cycling stability. Another approach is to fabricate SnO2/ carbon composite materials. The introduction of additional
[a] H. Xue,+ H. Gong, Prof. J. He College of Materials Science and Technology Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Materials and Technology for Energy Conversion Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics Nanjing 210016 (P.R. China) Fax: (+ 86) 25-5211-2626 E-mail : jianph@nuaa.edu.cn [b] Dr. J. Zhao+
Department of Mechanical & Industrial Engineering Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803 (USA)
[c] J. Tang, Prof. Y. Yamauchi World Premier International Center for Materials Nanoarchitectonics (WPI-MANA) National Institute for Materials Science (NIMS) 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba 305-0044 (Japan) E-mail : Yamauchi.Yusuke@nims.go.jp [d] H. Xue,+ Prof. H. Zhou Energy Technology Research Institute National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST) Tsukuba 305-8568 (Japan) Fax: (+ 81) 29-8613489 E-mail : hs.zhou@aist.go.jp
[e] Prof. P. He, Prof. H. Zhou National Laboratory of Solid State Microstructures and Center of Energy Storage Materials and Technology Nanjing University, Nanjing 210093 (P.R. China)
[+] These authors contributed equally to this work.
Supporting information for this article is available on the WWW under http ://dx.doi.org/10.1002/chem.201504420.
Chem. Eur. J. 2016, 22, 4915 – 4923 Ó 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim4915
carbon materials has been extensively reported to enhance the electrochemical performance of SnO2 anodes. Carbon materials, either as supporting matrices or surface coatings, can function as an effective buffer to release harmful reaction strains
and offer better electronic conductivity and lithium-ion diffusion efficiency. Lou et al.[20] designed and synthesized bowl-like SnO2@carbon hollow particles with a conformal carbon support, which exhibit a high capacity, a stable cyclability, and an excellent rate capability due to the reduced excessive hollow
interior space while retaining the general advantages of hollow structures. Therefore, fabricating SnO2/carbon composite materials in a delicate nanoarchitecture could be an effective way to achieve alternative anode materials with excellent
electrochemical performance for superior LIBs. Ordered mesoporous carbon (OMC) has been extensively re-
ported to be used in various applications for energy storage and conversion systems, including supercapacitors,[21–23] fuel cells,[24–26] catalysts,[27–29] solar cells,[30–32] and LIBs.[33–35] OMC ma-
terials have distinct advantages with respect to an uniform and interconnected pore structure, tailorable pore sizes,
a large surface area, a high pore volume, an outstanding thermal stability and conductivity, and a flexible framework struc-
ture. As for LIBs, OMC has been investigated as a framework to
accommodate lithium-active materials and works as an alternative anode in LIBs. Li et al.[36] employed as-prepared OMC with a high surface area of 2390 m2 g¢1 and a large pore diameter of 6.7 nm, which exhibited a high initial discharge capacity of 1048 mAh g¢1 at 0.1 C and retained a reversible capacity of 500 mAh g¢1 after 500 cycles when being used as an anode material in LIBs. Jin et al.[37] successfully loaded SnO2 nanoparticles in the three-dimensional mesoporous channel of CMK-3. Such composite materials can deliver a discharge capacity of 1054 mAh g¢1 at a current density of 200 mA g¢1, indicating an excellent rate capability. Fan et al.[38] reported the same work
about an ordered, tin-based oxide/carbon composite material by fully depositing Sn-based oxides into the 3D channels of mesoporous carbon, resulting in a better cycling performance
in comparison with pristine nanosized Sn-based oxide particles. Zhou et al.[39] reported the synthesis of a highly loaded SnO2/ mesoporous carbon (MC) nanohybrid by using 3D MC as a buffering and conducting matrix, exhibiting an improved cycling
stability and rate capability. As reported in literature,[37–42] ex situ impregnation methods
are always utilized to integrate SnO2-based materials into OMC materials, during which tin salt precursor solutions are intentionally introduced into 3D mesoporous channels of an as-pre-
pared OMC matrix, followed by post-annealing processes to obtain SnO2/OMC composite materials. Such ex situ synthetic approaches lead to unsatisfactory structures of the SnO2/OMC materials. The SnO2 particles are usually blocked in the OMC channels or only cover the surface of the OMC, which is highly
dependent on the permeability of the tin precursor solutions, the hydrophilic property of the OMC, and the pore size of the
mesoporous channels ; hence, it is difficult to lodge SnO2 particles in an OMC framework with good dispersity. In addition, ex
situ loading of SnO2 particles in as-prepared OMC generally results in weak physical contact between the SnO2 guest and the
OMC host due to the lack of chemical binding forces. Moreover, the outermost part of the mesoporous channels is easily blocked by post-attached SnO2 particles after heat treatments, which would seriously influence the penetration of the electro-
lyte. Herein, we report an in situ method to prepare SnO2/ordered mesoporous carbon composite materials through an
evaporation-induced self-assembly method followed by a postannealing process. The resultant SnO2@OMC material preserves a satisfactory ordered mesoporous structure of the OMC
framework, in which a high weight percentage of approximately 80 wt % SnO2 nanoparticles (NPs) are uniformly dispersed. The SnO2@OMC nanocomposite as an anode material for LIBs reveals synergistic effects from a high-capacity SnO2based anode material and the multifunctional OMC matrix, resulting in a high specific capacity, a remarkable cycling stability,
and an outstanding rate capability. Our work offers an effective
approach to integrate high-capacity anode materials into ordered mesoporous carbon, which can serve as an alternative
anode material for high-performance lithium-ion batteries.

sections.heading: Synthesis of materials
sections.text:
Preparation of ordered mesoporous carbon (OMC)
The low-molecular-weight resol (phenol-formaldehyde, Mw<500) precursors were prepared according to the procedure reported by Zhao et al.[43] OMC was synthesized through a solvent evaporationinduced self-assembly (EISA) method with Pluronic F127 (MW = 12 600, Sigma–Aldrich) as a template. Typically, F127 (1.0 g) was first dissolved in ethanol (20.0 g) with vigorous stirring for 30 min at 40 8C, and then a resol solution (5.0 g, 20 wt % in ethanol) was added. After stirring for additional 10 min, a homogeneous solution was stored at room temperature overnight to evaporate the ethanol, followed by thermopolymerization at 100 8C for 24 h in vacuum. For the carbonization process, the as-prepared membrane was transferred into a tube furnace and treated at 350 8C for 3 h and 900 8C for 2 h at a heating rate of 1 8C min¢1 under pure N2 protection. The products were obtained when cooling to room temperature and marked as OMC.

sections.heading: Ex situ loading of SnO2 nanoparticles on ordered mesoporous carbon (SnO2/OMC)
sections.text: The as-prepared OMC (1.0 g) was dispersed in a 0.1 m solution of SnCl2·2 H2O in ethanol (10 mL). The mixture was stirred for 12 h at room temperature and then stewed for additional 24 h. Subsequently, the mixed solution was stirred continuously at 60 8C until the ethanol was completely evaporated. After drying the resultant sample at 80 8C for 6 h, the heat treatment of dried powders was carried out in a tubular furnace at 300 8C for 4 h at a heating rate of 5 8C min¢1 under air. The resultant product was marked as SnO2/ OMC with 62.1 wt % of SnO2, based on measurement by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) (Table S1 in the Supporting Information).

sections.heading: In situ preparation of the SnO2 nanoparticles embedded within ordered mesoporous carbon (SnO2@OMC)
sections.text:
In order to embed the SnO2 nanoparticles into the OMC in situ, a tin precursor was directly introduced during the synthesis of the
Chem. Eur. J. 2016, 22, 4915 – 4923 www.chemeurj.org Ó 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim4916
OMC. F127 (1.0 g) was first dissolved in ethanol (16.0 g) with vigorous stirring for 30 min at 40 8C until a homogeneous transparent solution was formed. Then an ethanolic solution containing 20 wt % resol (5.0 g) was added dropwise, resulting in an acidic solution with a pH of 4–6. Simultaneously, a certain amount of NH3·H2O (28 wt %) was used to adjust the pH value of the tin precursor (10 mL of a 0.1 m solution of SnCl2·2H2O in ethanol) to 4–6, the same as the pH value of the resol precursor solution. Then the tin precursor solution was subjected to an ultrasonic dispersion for 5 min, followed by adding the resulting white emulsion to the above-described OMC precursor solution. After stirring for another 10 min, the obtained yellow solution was transferred into flatbottom dishes to evaporate the ethanol at room temperature overnight; then they were thermopolymerized in a vacuum oven at 100 8C for 24 h. The resultant transparent film was collected and carbonized under a N2 atmosphere at 350 8C for 3 h with a heating rate of 1 8C min¢1, then at 500 8C for 4 h with a heating rate of 5 8C min¢1. The target product was obtained and marked as SnO2@OMC; the weight ratio of SnO2 reaches as high as 78.8 wt % in SnO2@OMC (Table S1 in the Supporting Information).

sections.heading: Structural and morphological characterization
sections.text: The actual SnO2 content of the different composite materials was analyzed by ICP-OES by using a Perkin–Elmer Optima 5300DV analyzer. The crystalline phases of the samples were identified through X-ray diffraction (XRD) under a Bruker D8 X-ray diffractionmeter with monochromatic CuKa radiation (l= 0.154056 nm). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed on a Perkin–Elmer PHI 550 spectrometer with AlKa radiation (1486.6 eV) as the X-ray source. The size and surface morphology of the samples were observed with an emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, 15.0 kV, Hitachi-S4800). A transmission electron microscope (TEM, 200 kV, JEM-2100) was used to investigate the diameter and the distribution of the SnO2 particles within the ordered mesoporous carbon framework as well as the structural characteristics of the SnO2 particles. The porous structures of the powder samples were measured by a N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm by using a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 analyzer at 77 K. The specific surface area was calculated by using the Brunauer– Emmett–Teller (BET) method based on the adsorption data in the partial pressure (P/P0) range of 0.05–0.2. The pore-volume and pore-size distribution derived from the adsorption branch of the isotherms were estimated based on the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model. The total pore volume (Vpore) was computed from the adsorbed amount at a relative pressure (P/P0) of 0.992.

sections.heading: Electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
The mixture of the electrode materials was composed of 80 wt % of the as-prepared composite materials, 10 wt % of acetylene black, and 10 wt % of poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) binder in 1-methyl2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) as solvent. The resultant slurry was pasted onto a copper current collector and dried at 120 8C overnight under vacuum. The electrode was then pressed under a pressure of approximately 200 kg cm¢2, followed by cutting into circular strips 16 mm in diameter. There were approximately 2.5 mg of active materials being loaded onto each electrode.
The homemade testing cells were assembled in an argon-filled glovebox with concentrations of trace H2O and O2, both less than 1 ppm. The electrolyte was 1 m LiPF6 dissolved in ethylene carbonate (EC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) at a volumetric ratio of 1:1. All as-fabricated electrodes were served as the anode, with a metallic lithium foil as the counter and reference electrode and a Cel-
gard-2400 membrane as the separator. Galvanostatic charge/discharge reactions were performed in a voltage range of 0.005–3.0 V on a CT2001A LAND Battery Analyzer at different current densities. The lithium storage capacities of all composite anodes were calculated based on the mass of SnO2. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were carried out at a scanning rate of 1 mV s¢1 in a voltage range of 0.005–3.0 V on the electrochemical workstation (CHI660C). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were obtained by using a Solartron 1260 frequency response analyzer coupled to a Solartron 1287 potentiostat at frequencies between 100 kHz and 0.01 Hz. The amplitude of the sinusoidal potential signal was 10 mV.

sections.heading: Structural characterizations of OMC, SnO2/OMC, and SnO2@ OMC
sections.text:
Scheme 1 (part I) shows the preparation of the SnO2@OMC composite materials, which were synthesized in situ by an EISA
strategy followed by post-annealing processes. The soluble phenol-formaldehyde oligomers were used as carbon precur-
sors, F127 as template, and SnCl2 as the tin source. During the EISA process, F127, a phenolic resin precursor, and a tin salt
precursor can be uniformly mixed in the solvent ethanol, resulting in the formation of a rod micelle structure after evaporating the solvent.[44] Subsequently, pyrolysis of the copolymer
F127 template at 350 8C yields the resultant pore structure within the intermediate materials. Meanwhile, thermal poly-
merization of the phenolic resin precursor produces the desirable 3D framework. The final carbonization of the OMC materi-
als and the formation of SnO2 NPs can be achieved with a heat treatment at 900 8C. It is critical to control the pH value of the
Scheme 1. Schematic representation showing the preparation of SnO2@OMC and SnO2/OMC composite materials.
Chem. Eur. J. 2016, 22, 4915 – 4923 www.chemeurj.org Ó 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim4917
precursor solution when the carbon precursors and the tin salt are dissolved in ethanol during the process of preparing the
SnO2@OMC composites. The pH value could affect the formation of the rod micelles and the corresponding ordered meso-
porous structure of the SnO2@OMC composite materials. Because the pH value of the pure OMC precursor solution can be
found at around 6.5, the relative pH value of the SnCl2·2 H2O solution in ethanol was adjusted by using NH3·H2O before mixing with the above-described OMC precursor solution. Al-
though a few white participates of hydroxide tin are formed due to the manipulation of the pH value, the tin precursor can still be homogeneously dispersed within the OMC precursor solution, as both solutions have the same pH value, and thus successfully encapsulated into the ordered micellar colloids, which are composed of the soluble phenolic resin and F127
under vigorous stirring. As a result, the SnO2 NPs are introduced in situ into the ordered mesoporous carbon framework after the EISA process and the heat treatments. In contrast, the
fabrication process for the ex situ preparation of SnO2/OMC is illustrated in Scheme 1,part II). Theoretically, a tin precursor can
be impregnated into the mesoporous channels of the carbon matrixes through capillary action. A subsequent thermal treat-
ment at 300 8C for 4 h under an air atmosphere can lead to the formation of SnO2/OMC composites. However, the tin precursor was rarely impregnated into the internal structure of the
mesoporous channels, which may be due to the limited capillarity and hydrophobicity of the OMC. After annealing, the
SnO2 NPs blocked the opening of the ordered mesoporous channels and covered the surface of the OMC. Consequently, it
is difficult to introduce SnO2 NPs into the internal ordered mesoporous channels in the OMC by using an ex situ loading approach.
The wide-angle XRD patterns given in Figure 1 a reveal the crystal phases and relative purities of three different samples.
The XRD pattern of OMC exhibits two broad diffraction peaks at 2 q= 20–30 and 40–508, which can be indexed to (002) and (101) diffractions of amorphous carbon, respectively.[45] After ex
situ loading with SnO2 NPs, all characteristic XRD peaks of SnO2/OMC indicate the high purity of the SnO2 with the tetragonal rutile structure (JCPDS no. 41-1445). The broad diffraction peaks may be attributed to the small particle size of the SnO2 NPs. Although the annealing temperature for the heat treatment is low, namely, 300 8C, in order to avoid burning away of the OMC under air, the XRD pattern reveals the high crystallinity of the SnO2 NPs. For comparison purposes, the sintering temperature during the in situ preparation of SnO2@OMC was 500 8C under an inert N2 flow. Such heat treatment results not only in complete carbonization of the OMC material and removal of the surfactant template but also in obtaining a highly pure SnO2 phase. As a result, the SnO2@OMC composite material can be successfully achieved by using an in situ synthetic route, and the ordered mesoporous structure of the OMC has
been preserved (Figure 1 b). The wide-angle XRD pattern of
SnO2@OMC given in Figure 1 a indicates the tetragonal structure along with the high crystallinity of the SnO2 component due to the designed heat treatment process. As shown in Figure S1 in the Supporting Information, the XPS spectrum of
SnO2@OMC confirms the detailed elemental composition and the oxidation state of the SnO2, and there is an interaction between SnO2 and the OMC through a chemical bond (i.e. , a Sn¢ C bond). The detailed features of the XPS spectrum are discussed in the Supporting Information. In addition, the particle
size of the SnO2 NPs in both the SnO2/OMC and SnO2@OMC composites can be calculated by using the Scherrer equation
[Eq. (1)] associated with (110) and (101) peaks as follows:
D ¼ 0:89l B cos q
ð1Þ
in which D is the particle size, l is the wavelength of the X-ray
analysis (i.e. , CuKa, l= 0.154 nm), B is the half-peak width of the selected XRD peaks, and q is the Bragg angle. Accordingly,
the calculated average sizes of the SnO2 NPs for the SnO2/OMC and SnO2@OMC composites are 6.1 and 9.3 nm, respectively. The larger particle size of the SnO2 NPs from SnO2@OMC is probably due to the higher sintering temperature (500 8C) in comparison with that to prepare SnO2/OMC (300 8C). The higher the sintering temperature is, the larger is the particle size. The detailed features are discussed in the next section, re-
lated to TEM observations.
The pore-structure characteristics of the as-prepared OMC, SnO2/OMC, and SnO2@OMC materials are examined according to small-angle X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns, as shown in Fig-
ure 1 b. The OMC exhibits a distinct diffraction peak at a low range of 2 q= 1.08 and two weak peaks located at 2 q= 1.5 and 1.88, which are attributed to the (100), (110), and (200) diffractions, respectively, indicating a long-range ordered two-dimensional hexagonal (P6mm) mesoporous structure.[46] In contrast,
such characteristic diffraction peaks revealing the mesoporous features of the OMC cannot be detected in the small-angle
XRD pattern of the SnO2/OMC composite material. We speculate that the mesoporous channels of the OMC may be filled
or covered by SnO2 NPs in SnO2/OMC, because the SnO2 NPs were loaded ex situ onto the OMC matrix through the wet-
Chem. Eur. J. 2016, 22, 4915 – 4923 www.chemeurj.org Ó 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim4918
chemical method. In comparison with SnO2/OMC, the smallangle XRD pattern of SnO2@OMC shows a well-defined diffraction peak at 2 q= 1.08, which is indexed to the (100) diffraction, and thus confirms the reserved ordered mesoporous structure
of the OMC component within the SnO2@OMC composite materials through the in situ preparation process. It is reasonable
that in situ introduction of SnO2 NPs into the OMC framework would affect the structural ordering of the parent OMC to some extent, which can be seen from the decreased intensity
of the (100) diffraction peak and the disappearance of the (110) and (200) reflections of SnO2@OMC in comparison with that of the pristine OMC material as shown in Figure 1 b. There are two possible reasons: 1) the existence of a tin precursor
may influence the stability and distribution of the triblock copolymer F127 micelles during the EISA process; and 2) volu-
metric strains resulting from the crystal growth of embedded
SnO2 NPs probably lead to the reduced order degree of the mesoporous structure of the OMC host.
Figures 1 c and d show the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore-size distributions of the
OMC, SnO2/OMC, and SnO2@OMC materials, respectively. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method and the Barrett–Joyner–
Halenda (BJH) model were utilized to analyze the structural
pore characteristics of the three samples, including the BET surface area (SBET), the average pore size (D), and the total pore volume (Vtotal). All results are summarized in Table 1. As shown
in Figure 1 c, all samples exhibit type-IV curves of nitrogen ad-
sorption–desorption isotherms with an H1-type hysteresis loop.[47] As reported in literature,[27–29] the nitrogen uptake
during a relative pressure P/P0 range of 0.40–0.70 typically responds to the capillary condensation of nitrogen within the
one-dimensional cylindrical channels of the mesoporous materials. The pristine OMC delivers a very high SBET of 741.8 m
2 g¢1, along with a Vtotal of 0.55 cm
3 g¢1 and a D of 4.3 nm, indicating the typically mesoporous characteristics of OMC material. The distinguishing structures of SnO2/OMC and SnO2@OMC can be demonstrated by using SEM and TEM observations, which will be discussed later. As for the SnO2/OMC composite material, because most of the SnO2 NPs are covered at the surface of the OMC framework, such ex situ loading of SnO2, to some extent, fills out the outermost parts of the mesoporous channels of the OMC, resulting in a lower SBET of 459.9 m 2 g¢1 in comparison with that of the OMC. In addition, a few embed-
ded SnO2 NPs remaining at the center of the mesoporous channels also lead to a reduced surface area of SnO2/OMC. As shown in Figure 1 d and by the corresponding D values in Table 1, the OMC and SnO2/OMC have the same pore-size dis-
tribution centered at 4.3 nm, revealing that ex situ loading of the SnO2 NPs has little effect on the mesoporous structure of the OMC supporting framework. In the case of SnO2@OMC, the capillary condensation step of the isotherm shows a smoother
curve than that of the OMC in Figure 1 c. We speculate that the low calcination temperature, together with effects of em-
bedded SnO2 NPs on the final mesoporous structure, probably causes such a phenomenon. It is interesting to find that SnO2@ OMC has the largest pore-size distribution, between 5 and
6 nm, among the three samples and shows a higher SBET of 470.3 m2 g¢1 in comparison with 459.9 m2 g¢1 for SnO2/OMC, indicating that SnO2 can effectively prevent a structure collapse and the contraction of the mesoporous channels during car-
bonization at a low calcination temperature. Overall, all characterizations illustrate that in situ loading of the SnO2 NPs into the OMC matrix can retain the well-ordered mesoporous struc-
ture of the resulting SnO2@OMC composite material, together with a high specific surface area, a large pore size, and a desir-
able pore volume. Such a structure results in an unexpectedly remarkable electrochemical performance when SnO2@OMC is used as an alternative anode material for lithium-ion batteries. The SEM and field-emission (FE)-SEM images given in Fig-
ure S2 in the Supporting Information and Figures 2 a, d, and g
compare and distinguish the structural characteristics of OMC, SnO2/OMC, and SnO2@OMC. As shown in Figure S2 a in the Supporting Information, te OMC has an average particle size of approximately 5 mm, with very smooth facets. The correspond-
ingly magnified FE-SEM image given in Figure 2 a exhibits twodimensional and long-range ordered mesoporous channels
along with a uniform pore-size distribution. In comparison
with the pristine OMC material, the SnO2/OMC particles present a rougher surface morphology (Figure S2 b in the Support-
ing Information). In addition, the high-resolution FE-SEM image given in Figure 2 d shows that the surface of the OMC blocks is
almost covered with highly dense SnO2 NPs with an estimated mean particle size of less than 10 nm, and these tiny loaded SnO2 NPs are dispersive. However, it is difficult to see the ordered mesoporous channels, which probably lead to the loss
Table 1. Pore-structure parameters of OMC, SnO2/OMC, and SnO2@OMC samples.
Sample SBET [m 2 g¢1] Vpore [cm 3 g¢1] Dpore [nm]
OMC 741.8 0.55 4.3 SnO2/OMC 459.9 0.39 4.3 SnO2@OMC 470.3 0.39 5.6
Chem. Eur. J. 2016, 22, 4915 – 4923 www.chemeurj.org Ó 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim4919
of the characteristic peak representative of ordered mesoporous structure of OMC in the small-angle XRD characterization
(Figure 1 b). It seems that the SnO2 NPs are mostly loaded on the surface of the OMC through ex situ infiltration of the tin
precursor solution into the OMC material. In contrast, as shown in Figure S2 c in the Supporting Information and in Fig-
ure 2 g, SnO2@OMC not only reveals a similar morphology and average particle size to those of OMC (Figure S2 a in the Supporting Information and Figure 2 a) but also shows distinctly
reversed mesoporous channels at the surface of SnO2@OMC (Figure S2 c in the Supporting Information and Figure 2 g). As compared to the perfectly ordered mesoporous structure of pristine OMC (Figures 1 b and 2 a), SnO2@OMC displays slightly disordered features in Figure 2 g, which is inconsistent with the XRD results shown in Figure 1 b, which probably can be attrib-
uted to the in situ introduction of the SnO2 NPs. On the other hand, in comparison with the coarse surface of SnO2/OMC covered with SnO2 NPs (Figure 2 d), the SnO2 NPs are embedded within the OMC matrix of SnO2@OMC (Figure 2 g), indicating significantly different structures and combination modes be-
tween the OMC and SnO2 for the SnO2/OMC and SnO2@OMC composite materials.
Accordingly, the TEM and HR-TEM images of different sam-
ples are shown in Figure 2 in order to examine the detailed structures of the as-prepared materials. Figures 2 b and c exhibit
the highly ordered mesoporous channels of the OMC in perfectly parallel characteristics showing the (110) direction, which
corresponds to the two-dimensional hexagonal (p6mm) structure, which is in good agreement with the small-angle XRD
pattern (Figure 1 b). The relative pore size of the OMC is esti-
mated to be approximately 5 nm in the HR-TEM observations shown in Figure 2 c, revealing an extremely high-ordered mes-
oporous structure with an average pore-size distribution. As shown in Figure 2 e, although the ordered mesoporous chan-
nels cannot be seen in the FE-SEM image given in Figure 2 d, the TEM image of SnO2/OMC obviously exhibits such an ordered mesoporous structure. It is found that the outermost
tops of these ordered mesoporous channels are blocked by SnO2 NPs, and only a few SnO2 NPs exist in the internal structure of the OMC framework. Here, we tend to conclude that the ex situ loading approach leads to the surface coverage of
the OMC by SnO2 NPs together with the preserved structural characteristics of OMC; it is difficult to introduce SnO2 NPs into the internal parts of the ordered mesoporous channels in OMC. Figure 2 f shows an average particle size of approximately 5 nm and the high crystallinity of the embedded SnO2 NPs, which concur with the XRD result given in Figure 1 a. In contrast, as shown in Figures 2 h and i, SnO2@OMC reveals ordered mesoporous channels in spite of the slightly reduced degree of order, in which numerous SnO2 NPs are embedded in the internal structure of the OMC matrix. Furthermore, the SnO2 NPs have an average particle size of approximately 10 nm in high crystallinity, which is in accordance with the XRD result shown
in Figure 1 a. In comparison with the SnO2/OMC composite covered by SnO2 NPs at its surface, the SnO2 NPs are almost distributed within the ordered structure of the SnO2@OMC material rather than at the surface. The high-loading property of
SnO2 NPs within SnO2@OMC can also be clearly seen in Figures 2 h and S3 in the Supporting Information. In addition, the
lattice fringe of SnO2 marked in Figure 2 i illustrates the high crystallinity of the embedded SnO2 NPs, related to the interplanar distance of approximately 0.34 nm for the tetragonal rutile (110) facet of SnO2. In summary, the TEM observations clearly show the structural difference of SnO2@OMC in comparison with that of SnO2/OMC, indicating the merits of the in situ synthetic method to prepare nanostructured OMC-based metal
oxide composite materials.
Electrochemical performance of the OMC, SnO2/OMC, and SnO2@OMC materials
The lithium storage properties of SnO2-based ordered mesoporous carbon composite materials as alternative anode materials for LIBs are evaluated by using a two-electrode cell system, in which the as-prepared samples serve as working electrodes and metallic lithium foil acts as the counter and reference elec-
trodes. Figures 3 a–c show the galvanostatic charge/discharge
curves of the OMC, SnO2/OMC, and SnO2@OMC anodes in the 1st, 2nd, 5th, and 50th cycles in a voltage range of 0.005–3.0 V versus Li+/Li at a current density of 50 mA g¢1. All specific capacities are calculated based on the total mass of the active anode materials. OMC delivers a high initial discharge and charge capacity of 1323 and 343 mAh g¢1, respectively, with a low initial Coulombic efficiency of 25.9 %. Such a common
electrochemical phenomenon can be attributed to decomposition of the electrolyte and subsequent formation of the solid
electrolyte interphase (SEI) film on the large surface areas of OMC during the first cycle.[48, 49] As indicated in Figure 3 b, SnO2/OMC shows higher specific discharge and charge capacities of 1450 and 843 mAh g¢1 in the first cycle, respectively, corresponding to an improved Coulombic efficiency of 58.1 %
in comparison with that of pristine OMC. Accordingly, ex situ loading of SnO2 NPs on the OMC framework results in an in-
Chem. Eur. J. 2016, 22, 4915 – 4923 www.chemeurj.org Ó 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim4920
creased specific capacity and an enhanced Coulombic efficiency of the SnO2/OMC anode. It is noticeable that the in situ introduction of SnO2 NPs into the OMC matrix contributes to a much better electrochemical performance of the SnO2@OMC anode material. The initial discharge and charge capacities of the SnO2@OMC anode reach 1495 and 943 mAh g
¢1, respectively, along with a higher Coulombic efficiency of 63.4 %, as shown in Figure 3 c. Figure 3 d compares the cycling performance of these three samples. The specific capacity of the OMC can be stabilized at approximately 250 mAh g¢1 after the first five cycles, indicating the outstanding cycling stability of the pristine OMC material, which probably can be attributed to the high electronic conductivity of OMC and its numerous in-
ternal ordered mesoporous channels for the reversible storage of lithium ions. The combination of SnO2 NPs and OMC into composite materials is favorable for increasing the specific ca-
pacities of anode materials. Moreover, restricting SnO2 NPs within the ordered mesoporous structure of the OMC matrix
contributes to the enhanced cycle stability of the SnO2 materials, because the volumetric strain during the lithiation and deli-
thiation of the SnO2 NPs could be effectively released within the ordered mesoporous channels of the OMC. As a result,
SnO2@OMC demonstrates a predictably high retained specific capacity of 950 mAh g¢1 and a remarkable cycling performance as a SnO2-based carbon composite anode material for lithiumion batteries (Figure 3 d). The effects of in situ preparation of SnO2@OMC on improving the electrochemical performance of the composite anode materials can be seen in comparison with that of SnO2/OMC, which was obtained by using an ex situ loading method. As shown in Figure 3 d, although SnO2@ OMC and SnO2/OMC deliver approximate initial discharge capacities around 950 mAh g¢1, SnO2@OMC can retain the desirable capacity of 646 mAh g¢1 after 50 cycles, much higher than the 285 mAh g¢1 of SnO2/OMC. Such electrochemical behaviors illustrate the necessity and merits of taking advantage of the synergistic effects of OMC and SnO2 anode materials and their combinations. More importantly, as shown in the built-in chart
of Figure 3 d, the SnO2@OMC nanocomposite also exhibits a good capacity retention at a current density of 160 mA g¢1 (0.2 C), delivering a high reversible capacity of 503 mAh g¢1
even after 100 cycles. Besides, the Coulombic efficiency of SnO2@OMC maintains above 97 % for the charge and discharge processes after three cycles, confirming the excellent reversibil-
ity. In addition, the Nyquist plots from AC impedance spectroscopy measurements are shown in Figure S4 in the Supporting Information. These plots clearly show that the diameter of the semicircle of the SnO2@OMC electrode is much smaller than that of the SnO2/OMC electrode, indicating the enhanced electronic conductivity of SnO2@OMC. Moreover, the SEM images of the SnO2@OMC and SnO2/OMC materials after 100 cycles at a current density of 160 mA g¢1 (0.2 C) are shown in Figure S5 in the Supporting Information. For SnO2/OMC, we can find a serious agglomeration and pulverization of the SnO2 NPs covered the surface of the OMC, leading to a poor cycle performance. In contrast, although the partial collapse of the structure can
be found, the ordered mesoporous structure of SnO2@OMC is still remained well as a whole, and there occurs no obvious ag-
glomeration and pulverization of the SnO2 NPs. This result indicates that the multifunctional OMC matrix of SnO2@OMC can act as a favorable buffer to release reaction strains for lithiation/delithiation of the embedded SnO2 NPs, which is beneficial to improve the cycle performance. We also compared this work with other typical SnO2-based anode materials from some published literature,[39, 49, 50–57] as shown in Table S2 in the Supporting Information. Compared with those SnO2-based anode materials reported in literatures, the SnO2@OMC composite prepared in this work also shows a good electrochemical performance. The following reasons are suggested for the improved electrochemical performance of SnO2@OMC anode materials : 1) the high weight rate of the SnO2 component, up to 78.8 wt %, considerably increases the specific capacity of SnO2@OMC anodes because SnO2 has a theoretical capacity of 790 mAh g¢1, which is higher than that of OMC, that is, 605 mAh g¢1; 2) the OMC component not only offers ordered mesoporous channels for penetration and accommodation of
the electrolyte, but also acts as a buffer to effectively release reaction strains of LixSn alloys and thus prevents the pulverization and agglomeration of active Sn-based anode materials during the cycling processes ; 3) OMC is more favorable for an
enhanced conductivity between SnO2 NPs and the entire anode. In contrast, the SnO2 NPs are mostly located on the surface of SnO2/OMC through ex situ combination, consequently leading to a poor cycling stability. All of the above-mentioned effects result in a better cycling performance and higher spe-
cific capacity of SnO2@OMC than those of the SnO2/OMC and OMC anode materials.
Figure 4 reveals the relative high-rate performance of
SnO2@OMC in comparison with OMC and SnO2/OMC under different current densities from 80 to 1600 mA g¢1. It is clear that SnO2@OMC demonstrates the best rate capability at all high rates. As shown in Figure 4, the SnO2@OMC composite anode exhibits high capacities of approximately 650, 560, 450, and 340 mAh g¢1 at current densities of 80, 160, 800, and 1600 mA g¢1 (i.e. , 0.1, 0.2, 1, 2 C), respectively. Furthermore, SnO2@OMC manifests outstanding electrochemical reversibility after initial cycles at 80 mAh g¢1. When such anode material is cycled back from 1600 to 80 mA g¢1 and subjected to a highrate trial, SnO2@OMC can still deliver a reversible capacity of about 600 mA g¢1 along with an outstanding cycling stability.
Chem. Eur. J. 2016, 22, 4915 – 4923 www.chemeurj.org Ó 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim4921
Accordingly, we propose an appropriate mechanism to explain the excellent electrochemical performance of the SnO2@ OMC composite anode by studying the results of its cyclic voltammetry (CV) behavior, which was carried out at a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s¢1 in a voltage range of 0.005–3.0 V versus Li/ Li+ . As shown in Figure 5, the CV curves in the first three
cycles reveal the corresponding lithiation and delithiation pro-
cesses of the SnO2@OMC materials. During the initial cathodic reaction, two reduction peaks are observed. The former broad
peak located at approximately 1.0 V is ascribed to the reduction of SnO2 to form metallic Sn and Li2O. [58–61] It is known that such a reduction of SnO2 is irreversible and causes a large irreversible capacity in the first cycle, which has been shown from the initial charge/discharge curves in Figure 3 c; thus, this re-
duction peak would disappear in the following cycles. The latter dominant reduction peak is very sharp below 0.5 V.
There are four contributions to this process : 1) the formation of LixSn (0<x<4.4) ; [42, 50–52] 2) the lithium insertion into the mesoporous structure of the OMC;[42] 3) the decomposition of
the electrolyte; and 4) the formation of an SEI film on the surface of the SnO2@OMC electrode.
[42, 61] As reported in the literature,[42] reactions 1) and 2) are both reversible, whereas the reactions 3) and 4) are irreversible for SnO2-based carbon composite anode materials. As indicated in Figure 3, reaction 1) mainly contributes to the high specific capacity of the SnO2@ OMC anode material, along with a minor capacity contribution
from the OMC (Figure 3 d). Correspondingly, the anodic park appears in a wide voltage range between 0.005 and 1.5 V,
which can be attributed to the main de-alloy of formed LixSn and the extraction of lithium ions from the OMC matrix. In the
second and third cycles, the cooperative effects of reversible
processes from LixSn and OMC materials result in a cathodic peak below 0.5 V and an anodic peak with a voltage range of
0.005–1.5 V. Figure 3 d shows the excellent cycling stability of OMC and the poor cycling performance of SnO2/OMC. Therefore, we suggest that in situ embedding of SnO2 NPs into the OMC framework significantly improves the cyclability of the
SnO2 anode material. The schematics in Figure 5 illustrate the alloy and de-alloy processes of LixSn after the initial reduction of SnO2. Because the reduced metallic Sn NPs are still restricted within the OMC matrix, the OMC can offer sufficient space for
the particle grown from the LixSn alloy during the lithiation process and act as a buffer to effectively release reaction
strains caused by a considerable volumetric change in the LixSn alloy (lower-left inset in Figure 5).
[16] When the de-alloy of LixSn takes place (upper-left inset in Figure 5), the composite structure tends to recover to a great extent, that is, the Sn NPs are still restricted within the OMC matrix. As a result, the combination of SnO2 and OMC into a SnO2@OMC composite material considerably improves the electrochemical reversibility of
SnO2 anode materials in our case, which provides a new route to prepare SnO2-based high-performance anode materials for superior lithium-ion batteries.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
The remarkable electrochemical performance of SnO2-based carbon composite materials (SnO2@OMC) has been demonstrated as an anode material for lithium-ion batteries, in which
SnO2 NPs are embedded in situ within the ordered mesoporous structure of the OMC material with a very high weight
rate up to 80 wt %. The SnO2 NPs have an average particle size of approximately 10 nm and show high purity and crystallinity.
Furthermore, this composite shows a mean pore size of about 6 nm and a high surface area of 470.3 m2 g¢1. Such fabrication of SnO2@OMC composite materials contributes to an enhanced cycling performance during the alloy and de-alloy processes of LixSn after the initial reduction of the SnO2 material and thus results in a high specific capacity, an outstanding cycling stability, and a desirable rate capability of the SnO2@OMC anode materials. The SnO2@OMC anode can deliver a high initial charge capacity of 943 mAh g¢1 and retain 646 mAh g¢1 after 50 cycles, even exhibit a capacity of 503 mA h g¢1 after 100 cycles at 160 mA g¢1. When cycled at a high current density of 1600 mA g¢1, a satisfactory capacity of 339 mAh g¢1 can also be achieved. The synthetic strategy in this paper for designing ordered mesoporous carbon-based composite materials can be
extended to fabricate other high-performance anode materials,
which offers a facile approach to improve the electrochemical performance of next-generation lithium-ion batteries.

references.title: Schematics illustrating the Li insertion/extraction processes of the SnO2@OMC anode material along with the relative cyclic voltammetry curves
author: M. Yoshio
H.Y. Wang
K. Fukuda
T. Umeno
N. Dimov
Z. Ogumi
J. Electrochem. Soc

referenceMentions.context: One strategy is to develop nanostructured SnO2 materials, such as nanofibers, [17] nanosheets,([18]) and hollow structures,([19]) which have been demonstrated to mini-
88, which are attributed to the (100), (110), and (200) diffractions, respectively, indicating a long-range ordered two-dimensional hexagonal (P6mm) mesoporous structure.([46]) In contrast,
[42, 61] As reported in the literature,([42]) reactions 1) and 2) are both reversible, whereas the reactions 3) and 4) are irreversible for SnO2-based carbon composite anode materials.

metadata.abstractText: Tin oxide nanoparticles (SnO2 NPs) have been encapsulated in situ in a three-dimensional ordered space structure. Within this composite, ordered mesoporous carbon (OMC) acts as a carbon framework showing a desirable ordered mesoporous structure with an average pore size (6 nm) and a high surface area (470.3 m g¢1), and the SnO2 NPs (10 nm) are highly loaded (up to 80 wt %) and homogeneously distributed within the OMC matrix. As an anode material for lithium-ion batteries, a SnO2@OMC composite material can deliver an initial charge capacity of 943 mAh g¢1 and retain 68.9 % of the initial capacity after 50 cycles at a current density of 50 mA g¢1, even exhibit a capacity of 503 mA h g¢1 after 100 cycles at 160 mA g¢1. In situ encapsulation of the SnO2 NPs within an OMC framework contributes to a higher capacity and a better cycling stability and rate capability in comparison with bare OMC and OMC ex situ loaded with SnO2 particles (SnO2/OMC). The significantly improved electrochemical performance of the SnO2@ OMC composite can be attributed to the multifunctional OMC matrix, which can facilitate electrolyte infiltration, accelerate charge transfer, and lithium-ion diffusion, and act as a favorable buffer to release reaction strains for lithiation/delithiation of the SnO2 NPs.
metadata.creator: Arbortext Advanced Print Publisher 9.1.580/W
